admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project outcome is assessed
            as marginally satisfactory, since project development
            objectives were only partially achieved. Sustainability of
            the credit component is uncertain, but the success achieved
            under the technical assistance component, assesses a
            probable sustainability. The lessons indicate that,
            particularly in transition economies, the catalytic role of
            government in the provision of funds to private sector
            activities, should be carefully defined during project
            preparation, which might help in avoiding the negative
            impact government subsidies have, on the implementation of
            commercial credit lines. Incidentally, credit lines should
            be designed within an overall strategy for banking sector
            development, including capital markets, and avoid overly
            complex eligibility criteria. Instead, emphasis should be
            placed on the overall institutional capacity of
            participating banks, including risk assessment, asset,
            liability, and liquidity management, in order to enhance the
            sustainability of a credit operation. Similarly, upon
            lending to private investors, terms and conditions should be
            flexible, to allow modifications when changing market
            conditions so require. However, it should be mentioned that
            a strong reliance on grant financing, may be conducive to
            financial management neglect, unless a cost-recovery scheme
            is built in early on.
